description._content: Infinite Island: Contemporary Caribbean Art August 31, 2007–January 27, 2008 Hew Locke (b. United Kingdom 1959) VITA, VERITAS, VICTORIA (LIFE, TRUTH, VICTORY), 2007 Cord, beads, tape, and glue Courtesy of the artist New work created for the exhibition Locke’s recent work is based on the Western heraldic motif of the royal coat of arms, depicted on every British passport. The artist incorporates and absorbs imagery from other cultures in order to reflect, as he states, “the changing/shifting nature of British cultural identity and the fear these changes often evoke.” He makes reference to the coats of arms of Caribbean countries—national icons that, although derived from European traditions, incorporate symbols of native peoples’ arts and environments. Here Locke interweaves designs from various works displayed in the Brooklyn Museum’s collection, including the Paracas Textile and Nasca pots originating from Peru and African masks. The image at the center of this intricate design is a direct reference to a work in the collection by the French sculptor Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux titled A Negress (1868), which was an ethnographic study for the personification of Africa in a fountain of the four continents in the Luxembourg Gardens. According to Locke, his work “symbolizes layers of history that have impacted British cultural identity.” Tamara's Blog Post Uploaded for Tell a story in 5 frames
